title: How to Get Permanent Ink Off Windows

steps.headline: Ventilate the area and put on plastic gloves.
steps.description: WD-40 is a strong chemical, so crack a nearby window or work in a well-ventilated area. Put on a pair of plastic gloves to protect your hands. Extinguish any flames nearby, such as candles. WD-40 is highly flammable.

steps.headline: Spray a liberal amount of WD-40 on the ink-stained area.
steps.description: Point the nozzle toward the glass and spray the area liberally with WD-40. Allow it to soak for 3-5 minutes. If you're dealing with a particularly old ink stain, you may want to cover the area with plastic wrap while it soaks. If the ink is relatively new, this probably isn't necessary.

steps.headline: Dampen a clean cloth with water.
steps.description: Run a soft microfiber cloth under the tap, then wring it out until it's damp. If you're working on a small or hard to reach area, use damp cotton balls or cotton swabs instead.

steps.headline: Touch the cloth directly on the stain.
steps.description: Gently touch the damp cloth on the ink stain only. Scrub with short strokes and stay close to the stain. If you wipe the surface with large strokes, the ink will smear across it and you'll have another mess to clean!

steps.headline: Apply more WD-40 if necessary.
steps.description: If the stain hasn't completely lifted after your initial scrub, spray the area with WD-40 again. Let it soak for another 3-5 minutes. Repeat the scrubbing until the ink has completely lifted.

steps.headline: Dampen a clean cloth and wipe away the WD-40 residue.
steps.description: Run a clean microfiber cloth under warm water, then wring it out. Wipe the surface of the glass to rinse away the film of WD-40 on it.

steps.headline: Clean the surface with a glass cleaner.
steps.description: Spray the surface with glass cleaner, then use paper towels or another clean cloth to wipe away any remaining residue. The surface should now be free of ink and sparkling clean!

steps.headline: Soak a paper towel or clean cloth with rubbing alcohol.
steps.description: Rubbing alcohol, also known as isopropyl alcohol, is the same kind you have in your medicine cabinet. Grab the bottle and liberally apply the alcohol on a clean cloth or paper towel. If you have sensitive skin, you may want to wear plastic gloves while working with rubbing alcohol.

steps.headline: Wipe the ink stain with the alcohol-soaked cloth.
steps.description: Start with gentle swipes on the surface, since alcohol is quite effective. If needed, apply a little more pressure and continue to wipe at the stain. You'll see the alcohol starting to come off easily. If necessary, apply more rubbing alcohol to your rag and repeat the process.

steps.headline: Dampen a clean cloth with fresh water and rinse the glass.
steps.description: Run your cloth under the tap, then wring it out until it's just damp, not dripping. Rinse the glass surface by wiping it with the cloth.

steps.headline: Follow up with glass cleaner.
steps.description: Once rinsed, spray glass cleaner onto the surface of the glass. Use a clean cloth or sponge to wipe any remaining residue from the surface.

steps.headline: Work in a well-ventilated area.
steps.description: Acetone-based nail polish is a very strong solvent. Crack a window and turn on the ceiling fan to keep air-flow moving. Is possible, work outside. If you have sensitive skin, you may want to wear plastic gloves while working with acetone.

steps.headline: Soak paper towels with the nail polish remover.
steps.description: Make sure you're using acetone-based nail polish! Non-acetone remover won't work. Uncap the bottle and pour it liberally on a wad of paper towels. You want the towels to be saturated with acetone.

steps.headline: Wipe the ink-stained surface.
steps.description: Acetone is strong and effective, so you shouldn't have to scrub the stain vigorously. Wipe the glass until all of the ink has lifted. Apply more acetone as needed.

steps.headline: Rinse the surface with a dampened cloth.
steps.description: Wet a clean cloth with water, then wring it out thoroughly so that it's damp, not soaked. Wipe the surface with the cloth to rinse away any acetone residue on the glass. If any acetone got on your hands, wash them with soap and water afterwards.

tyn: WD-40, rubbing alcohol or acetone-based nail polisher remover
text: Using WD-40 Spray Lubricant Ventilate the area and put on plastic gloves. WD-40 is a strong chemical, so crack a nearby window or work in a well-ventilated area. Put on a pair of plastic gloves to protect your hands. Extinguish any flames nearby, such as candles. WD-40 is highly flammable. Spray a liberal amount of WD-40 on the ink-stained area. Point the nozzle toward the glass and spray the area liberally with WD-40. Allow it to soak for 3-5 minutes. If you're dealing with a particularly old ink stain, you may want to cover the area with plastic wrap while it soaks. If the ink is relatively new, this probably isn't necessary. Dampen a clean cloth with water. Run a soft microfiber cloth under the tap, then wring it out until it's damp. If you're working on a small or hard to reach area, use damp cotton balls or cotton swabs instead. Touch the cloth directly on the stain. Gently touch the damp cloth on the ink stain only. Scrub with short strokes and stay close to the stain. If you wipe the surface with large strokes, the ink will smear across it and you'll have another mess to clean! Apply more WD-40 if necessary. If the stain hasn't completely lifted after your initial scrub, spray the area with WD-40 again. Let it soak for another 3-5 minutes. Repeat the scrubbing until the ink has completely lifted. Dampen a clean cloth and wipe away the WD-40 residue. Run a clean microfiber cloth under warm water, then wring it out. Wipe the surface of the glass to rinse away the film of WD-40 on it. Clean the surface with a glass cleaner. Spray the surface with glass cleaner, then use paper towels or another clean cloth to wipe away any remaining residue. The surface should now be free of ink and sparkling clean! Using Rubbing Alcohol Soak a paper towel or clean cloth with rubbing alcohol. Rubbing alcohol, also known as isopropyl alcohol, is the same kind you have in your medicine cabinet. Grab the bottle and liberally apply the alcohol on a clean cloth or paper towel. If you have sensitive skin, you may want to wear plastic gloves while working with rubbing alcohol. Wipe the ink stain with the alcohol-soaked cloth. Start with gentle swipes on the surface, since alcohol is quite effective. If needed, apply a little more pressure and continue to wipe at the stain. You'll see the alcohol starting to come off easily. If necessary, apply more rubbing alcohol to your rag and repeat the process. Dampen a clean cloth with fresh water and rinse the glass. Run your cloth under the tap, then wring it out until it's just damp, not dripping. Rinse the glass surface by wiping it with the cloth. Follow up with glass cleaner. Once rinsed, spray glass cleaner onto the surface of the glass. Use a clean cloth or sponge to wipe any remaining residue from the surface. Using Nail Polish Remover Work in a well-ventilated area. Acetone-based nail polish is a very strong solvent. Crack a window and turn on the ceiling fan to keep air-flow moving. Is possible, work outside. If you have sensitive skin, you may want to wear plastic gloves while working with acetone. Soak paper towels with the nail polish remover. Make sure you're using acetone-based nail polish! Non-acetone remover won't work. Uncap the bottle and pour it liberally on a wad of paper towels. You want the towels to be saturated with acetone. Wipe the ink-stained surface. Acetone is strong and effective, so you shouldn't have to scrub the stain vigorously. Wipe the glass until all of the ink has lifted. Apply more acetone as needed. Rinse the surface with a dampened cloth. Wet a clean cloth with water, then wring it out thoroughly so that it's damp, not soaked. Wipe the surface with the cloth to rinse away any acetone residue on the glass. If any acetone got on your hands, wash them with soap and water afterwards.

Uncap the bottle and pour it liberally on a wad of paper towels.
You want the towels to be saturated with acetone.
Wipe the ink-stained surface.
Acetone is strong and effective, so you shouldn't have to scrub the stain vigorously.
Wipe the glass until all of the ink has lifted.

If any acetone got on your hands, wash them with soap and water afterwards.
